channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Art critic on the impact the planned closure of the Kennedy Center could have
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Washington Post art and architecture critic Philip Kennicott about President Trump's plan to temporarily close the Kennedy Center.
item.content:encoded: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Washington Post art and architecture critic Philip Kennicott about President Trump's plan to temporarily close the Kennedy Center.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: Amid partial government shutdown, debate over DHS funding continues
item.description: The government is still in a partial shutdown, but the House Speaker predicts it will be over by Tuesday. In the meantime, lawmakers are still divided over Department of Homeland Security policy changes.
item.content:encoded: The government is still in a partial shutdown, but the House Speaker predicts it will be over by Tuesday. In the meantime, lawmakers are still divided over Department of Homeland Security policy changes.
item.dc:creator: Luke Garrett

item.title: House Minority Whip on partial government shutdown and DHS funding
item.description: Amid the partial government shutdown, we hear from House Minority Whip Rep. Katherine Clark, D-Mass., about funding for the Department of Homeland Security.
item.content:encoded: Amid the partial government shutdown, we hear from House Minority Whip Rep. Katherine Clark, D-Mass., about funding for the Department of Homeland Security.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Too old to compete? This 87-year-old triathlete has tips for staying in the game
item.description: Despite issues with her heart, this octogenarian still competes in triathlons. She's proof that preventive medicine paired with smart lifestyle choices help seniors stay active longer.
item.content:encoded:
Despite issues with her heart, this octogenarian still competes in triathlons. She's proof that preventive medicine paired with smart lifestyle choices help seniors stay active longer.

(Image credit: Shawn Green)
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: The Education Department's efforts to fire staff cost over $28 million, watchdog says
item.description: A new report from the U.S. Government Accountability Office calculates the cost of efforts to fire civil rights staff, and questions the department's ability to enforce federal civil rights laws.
item.content:encoded:
A new report from the U.S. Government Accountability Office calculates the cost of efforts to fire civil rights staff, and questions the department's ability to enforce federal civil rights laws.

(Image credit: Bill Clark)
item.dc:creator: Cory Turner

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Debate over DHS funding continues amid partial government shutdown, judge allows immigration enforcement surge to continue in Minnesota, Trump says Kennedy Center will close for construction.
item.content:encoded: Debate over DHS funding continues amid partial government shutdown, judge allows immigration enforcement surge to continue in Minnesota, Trump says Kennedy Center will close for construction.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Ice and snow snarl power grids, leaving thousands in the dark
item.description: Thousands of people are still without power after ice and snow gripped much of the country, rattling power grids and energy markets.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of people are still without power after ice and snow gripped much of the country, rattling power grids and energy markets.
item.dc:creator: Mose Buchele

item.title: New York Republican met with jeers during town hall in hotly contested district
item.description: Republican Rep. Mike Lawler of New York held his first town hall of the year Sunday, but he faced jeers, insults and questions about the recent events in Minneapolis and ICE tactics.
item.content:encoded: Republican Rep. Mike Lawler of New York held his first town hall of the year Sunday, but he faced jeers, insults and questions about the recent events in Minneapolis and ICE tactics.
item.dc:creator: Steve Kastenbaum

item.title: Gaza's Rafah border crossing with Egypt slated to reopen
item.description: Israel says it has allowed Gaza's Rafah border crossing with Egypt to reopen, a key step in the Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement. No one has crossed yet.
item.content:encoded: Israel says it has allowed Gaza's Rafah border crossing with Egypt to reopen, a key step in the Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement. No one has crossed yet.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Trump says Kennedy Center will close for 2 years for renovation
item.description: President Trump announced he plans to close the Kennedy Center for two years for remodeling, following massive backlash after his name was added to the building.
item.content:encoded: President Trump announced he plans to close the Kennedy Center for two years for remodeling, following massive backlash after his name was added to the building.
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
